uksc-2015-0177: Littlewoods overpaid VAT to HMRC between 1973 and 2004.
HMRC repaid the principal sum of 205 million to Littlewoods between 2005 and 2008.
HMRC also paid simple interest of 268 million to Littlewoods between 2005 and 2008.
Littlewoods seeks additional compound interest of 1.25 billion based on common law claims.
Littlewoods claims the compound interest is due under the common law of restitution.
The Supreme Court was asked to determine if common law claims are excluded by sections 78 and 80 of the 1994 Act.
The lower courts ruled that Littlewoods' common law claims were barred by the 1994 Act.
Littlewoods appeals the lower court's decision on the exclusion of common law claims.
The Supreme Court dismissed Littlewoods' cross appeal on the first issue.
The Supreme Court allowed HMRC's appeal on the second issue regarding EU law compliance.
uksc-2009-0105: JFS is designated as a Jewish faith school.
JFS has an oversubscription policy that gives precedence to children recognized as Jewish by the OCR.
The OCR recognizes a person as Jewish if they are descended in the matrilineal line from a Jewish woman or have undergone a qualifying Orthodox conversion.
E and M are practising Masorti Jews.
E is recognized as Jewish by the OCR, but M's mother is of Italian and Catholic origin.
M's mother converted to Judaism under the auspices of a non-Orthodox synagogue.
M's mother's conversion is not recognized by the OCR.
M's application to JFS was rejected because he did not meet the OCR's matrilineal descent requirement.
E challenged JFS's admissions policy as direct discrimination under the Race Relations Act 1976.
The Supreme Court ruled that JFS directly discriminated against M on grounds of his ethnic origins.
uksc-2017-0040: The Appellant and Respondent are former husband and wife.
They divorced in 2002 after a marriage of approximately fifteen years.
The financial issues in the divorce were resolved by a consent order.
The wife received 230,000 in settlement of her capital claims against the husband.
The husband agreed to make periodical payments to the wife at an annual rate of 13,200.
The husband anticipated the wife would use the 230,000 to purchase a home without a mortgage.
The wife took out a mortgage and purchased a more expensive home for 345,000.
Between 2002 and 2009, the wife sold and purchased a series of different properties.
The wife did not reinvest all sale proceeds into the next property and spent the balance.
By April 2015, the wife had no capital and debts of around 42,000.
The hearing was to determine two cross applications under s.31(1) of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973.
The husband applied for the discharge or downwards variation of the periodical payments order.
The wife applied for the periodical payments order to be varied upwards.
The judge noted a shortfall of 4,092 per annum between the wife's needs and the existing payments.
The judge held the wife had not managed her finances wisely, increasing her need to pay rent.
The judge concluded it would be unfair to require the husband to fully fund the wife's rental costs.
The judge declined to vary the periodical payments order.
The wife appealed and was successful in the Court of Appeal.
The Court of Appeal increased the periodical payments to 17,292 to cover the wife's shortfall.
The husband now appeals the decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allows the husband's appeal.
The Court of Appeal erred in saying the judge gave no reason for declining to increase payments.
The judge gave a clear reason for declining to increase payments.
The Court of Appeal should have considered the impact of the original capital payment on the wife's need to pay rent.
The Court of Appeal referenced three earlier cases: Pearce v Pearce, North v North, and Yates v Yates.
The judge was entitled, though not obliged, to decline to require the husband to fund the wife's rent.
The court has wide discretion under section 31(1) and (7) of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973.
A court must give very good reasons for requiring a spouse to fund the other's rent in these circumstances.
A spouse may be obliged to make provision for the other, but duplication of provision is improbable.
uksc-2011-0046: The appellants are 251 classroom assistants, support for learning assistants, and nursery nurses employed during school term time in the respondent's schools.
The appellants are employed under terms contained in the Blue Book, a national collective agreement.
The comparators are full-time manual workers employed by the respondent, including groundsmen, refuse collectors, refuse drivers, and a leisure attendant.
The comparators are entitled to a substantial supplement on top of their basic pay.
The appellants are not entitled to the same substantial supplement as the comparators.
The issue is whether the appellants are employed under less favourable terms and conditions than the comparators.
The Employment Tribunal ruled that the appellants are in the same employment as the comparators.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal allowed an appeal by the respondent, stating the appellants could not show a real possibility that the comparators could be employed in schools.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and restored the Employment Tribunal's decision.
The Supreme Court held that the same employment test does not require comparators to be employed at the same establishment as the claimants.
uksc-2011-0115: Section 6(1) of the Prosecution of Offences Act 1985 allows a private person to institute and conduct a private prosecution.
Section 6(2) of the 1985 Act gives the DPP the power to take over a private prosecution even when not under a duty to do so.
The DPP considers the strength of the evidence when deciding whether to take over a private prosecution.
Prior to 23 June 2009, the DPP used the "no case to answer" criterion to determine whether to take over a private prosecution.
On 23 June 2009, the DPP changed its policy to use the "reasonable prospect test" for deciding whether to take over a private prosecution.
The Appellant instituted two private prosecutions in August 2010.
The DPP took over and discontinued the two private prosecutions on 16 November 2010.
The Appellant applied for judicial review of the DPP's decision to take over and discontinue the prosecutions.
The Supreme Court dismissed the Appellant's appeal by a majority of 3:2.
Lord Wilson's judgment reaffirmed the right to private prosecution and supported the reasonable prospect test as a more relevant criterion than the previous "no case to answer" test.
uksc-2010-0127: The Buyers entered into six shipbuilding contracts with Jinse Shipbuilding Co Ltd in May 2007.
Each vessel was priced at US$33.3 million, to be paid in five equal instalments.
Payment of the first instalment was conditional upon the Builder providing a refund guarantee from a first-class Korean bank.
The Buyers had a right to a full refund if they rejected the vessel or terminated the contract.
The Buyers were entitled to repayment of instalments if the Builder defaulted, including insolvency.
The Respondent bank issued identical Advanced Payment Bonds to each Buyer in August 2007.
The Bonds stated the Respondent would pay sums due to the Buyers under the Contract upon written demand.
The Buyers paid the first instalment of US$6.66 million under the Contracts.
One Buyer also paid a second instalment of US$6.66 million.
The Supreme Court unanimously restored the High Court's ruling in favor of the Buyers.
uksc-2010-0039: The appeal concerns the scope of exceptions to the without prejudice rule.
The issue is whether statements from without prejudice negotiations can be used to interpret a resulting agreement.
TMT Asia Limited and others entered into forward freight agreements with Oceanbulk Shipping & Trading SA.
The appellants failed to pay a sum due under the forward freight agreements.
The parties entered into settlement negotiations expressed to be without prejudice.
The negotiations resulted in a written settlement agreement regarding the sum due.
The respondent brought a claim for damages alleging breach of the settlement agreement.
The appellants sought to rely on without prejudice negotiations to interpret the agreement.
The respondent argued that the without prejudice rule precluded the use of those statements.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal, recognizing the interpretation exception to the without prejudice rule.
uksc-2010-0231: The Appellants are employed to work on offshore oil and gas installations.
The Respondents are the employers of the Appellants.
Most Appellants were contracted to work a pattern of two weeks offshore followed by two weeks onshore.
While offshore, the Appellants generally worked 12-hour shifts each day.
During their offshore shifts, the Appellants had 12 hours off duty living on the installation.
The Appellants did not have any days off while they were offshore.
The Appellants were mostly free from work-related obligations during their field breaks.
The Working Time Regulations 1998 incorporate the provisions of the Working Time Directive 2003.
Workers are entitled to paid annual leave of at least four weeks under the Working Time Directive.
The Supreme Court dismissed the Appellants' appeal and affirmed the decision of the Court of Session.
uksc-2016-0052: The appellant was convicted of drug trafficking offences on 21 May 1999 and sentenced to 25 years imprisonment.
On 29 March 2000, the appellant was ordered to pay over 5.4 million by way of a confiscation order.
The confiscation order required the appellant to pay the amount within 12 months or serve six years imprisonment in default of payment.
On 4 May 2007, a receiver appointed to realise the appellant's assets paid 12,500.
The magistrates deducted seven days from the six-year term in default to account for the part payment.
At that time, interest had increased the net sum outstanding to 8.1 million after accounting for the part payment.
Later in 2007 and 2011, the appellant's receiver made further payments of 12,500 and 65,370 respectively.
The prison authorities calculated the reduction in the six-year default term based on the proportion of the payments to the 8.1 million at the time of his committal.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal regarding whether interest is included in the starting point for proportionate credit for part payment of a confiscation order.
The key provisions of the Drug Trafficking Act 1994 treat interest for enforcement purposes as part of the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order.
uksc-2012-0124: The appeal concerns whether the definition of terrorism in the Terrorism Act 2000 includes military attacks by non-state armed groups against national or international armed forces in a non-international armed conflict.
Mr Gul was convicted of five counts of disseminating terrorist publications.
The offence of disseminating terrorist publications was created by section 2 of the Terrorism Act 2006.
Section 2 of the Terrorism Act 2006 defines terrorist publications as those likely to encourage acts of terrorism.

Section 1 of the Terrorism Act 2000 defines terrorism as the use or threat of action involving serious violence, damage to property, or actions designed to influence a government or intimidate the public.
The videos in question included attacks by al Qaeda, the Taliban, and other proscribed groups on military targets in Chechnya, Iraq, and Afghanistan.
The videos also featured the use of improvised explosive devices against Coalition forces.
The videos included excerpts from martyrdom videos and clips of attacks on civilians, including the 11 September 2001 attack on the United States.
The videos were accompanied by commentaries praising the bravery and martyrdom of those carrying out the attacks and encouraging others to emulate them.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mr Gul's appeal, upholding the Court of Appeal's decision.
uksc-2009-0127: The original maximum sentence for driving while disqualified under the Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988 was six months imprisonment or the statutory fine.
The maximum sentence for driving while disqualified, when prosecuted on indictment, was 12 months imprisonment or a fine.
A committee recommended increasing the sentencing power of sheriffs sitting summarily in Scotland to 12 months.
The Criminal Proceedings etc (Reform)(Scotland) Act 2007 increased the maximum sentence for driving while disqualified to 12 months.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller were each sentenced to over six months imprisonment for driving while disqualified.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller challenged their sentences, arguing the 2007 Act was outside the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The High Court of Justiciary dismissed the appeals, stating the 2007 Act was within the Scottish Parliament's competence.
The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision, finding the 2007 Act was within the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The Supreme Court determined that s.45 of the 2007 Act modified a rule of Scots criminal procedure, not a reserved matter.
The court concluded that the sentencing jurisdiction of sheriffs in relation to road traffic offences was not special to the Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988.
uksc-2013-0266: The 2010 amendment to the Immigration Rules requires foreign spouses or partners of UK citizens to pass an English language test before entering the UK.
The Rule applies to both E ECP 4.1 and E LTRP 4.1 in Appendix FM.
The appellants challenged the Rule as an unjustifiable interference with their right to respect for private and family life under Article 8 of the ECHR.
The appellants also argued the Rule was unjustifiably discriminatory under Article 14 of the ECHR.
The UK government's objectives for the Rule included assisting integration, improving employment chances, and reducing vulnerability of newly arrived spouses.
The Rule requires spouses and partners to demonstrate basic English language skills by passing an approved test.
Exceptional circumstances for exemption from the English test are rarely considered and do not include financial reasons or lack of literacy.
The appellants are UK citizens married to foreigners since 2009 and 2010, respectively.
The High Court and Court of Appeal both found the Rule itself was not unlawful.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal but invited further submissions on whether the Guidance is incompatible with Article 8 rights in certain cases.
uksc-2013-0023: The vessel Alexandros T sank on 3 May 2006 and became a total loss 300 miles south of Port Elizabeth.
The sinking resulted in considerable loss of life.
The owners of the vessel were Starlight Shipping Company.
Starlight made a claim against their insurers.
The insurers denied liability on the basis that the vessel was unseaworthy with the privity of Starlight.
Starlight made serious allegations against their insurers, including misconduct involving tampering with and bribing of witnesses.
Starlight issued proceedings in the Commercial Court against various insurers on 15 August 2006.
The insurers were divided into two groups: the Company Market Insurers (CMI) and the Lloyds Market Insurers (LMI).
The 2006 proceedings were settled between Starlight and the insurers, and the proceedings were stayed by way of a Tomlin Order.
In April 2011, nine sets of Greek proceedings were issued by Starlight, expressed as torts actionable in Greece.
uksc-2012-0247: The appeals concern extradition requests under European arrest warrants (EAWs).
The Lithuanian Ministry of Justice issued an EAW for Mindaugas Bucnys based on a conviction for housebreaking and fraud.
The Lithuanian Ministry of Justice issued an EAW for Marius Sakalis based on a conviction for sexual assaults.
The Estonian Ministry of Justice issued an EAW for Dimitri Lavrov based on a conviction for murder.
EAWs are intended to meet the requirements of Council Framework Decision 2002/584/JHA on surrender procedures between EU member states.
Part 1 of the UK Extradition Act 2003 was enacted to give effect to the same requirements as the Framework Decision.
Section 2(7) of the 2003 Act requires EAW requests to be certified by the Serious Organised Crime Agency (SOCA), now the National Crime Agency (NCA).
The appeals raise questions about whether the EAW requests were based on judicial decisions by a judicial authority within the terms of the Framework Decision and the 2003 Act.
The Supreme Court held that the EAWs for Mr. Bucnys and Mr. Lavrov were valid, while the EAW for Mr. Sakalis was not.

The Supreme Court ruled that a ministry of justice can be considered a judicial authority if it is sufficiently independent of the executive and acts on the request of a court or other judicial authority.
uksc-2012-0249: Three young British servicemen died and two others were seriously injured in Iraq.
The Challenger claims involve a friendly fire incident with British tanks.
Cpl Stephen Allbutt died and Lance Cpl Daniel Twiddy and Tpr Andrew Julien were seriously injured in the friendly fire incident.
The Challenger claims allege failures by the Ministry of Defence to properly equip the tanks and provide adequate recognition training.
The Snatch Land Rover claims involve the deaths of Pte Phillip Hewett and Pte Lee Ellis.
The claimants in the Snatch Land Rover claims allege the MoD breached the implied positive obligation under Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
The Ellis negligence claim is brought by Courtney Ellis and alleges various failures by the MoD.
The MoD argued the Snatch Land Rover claims should be struck out due to lack of jurisdiction and no duty of care.
The High Court and Court of Appeal ruled that the Challenger claims and Ellis negligence claim should proceed to trial.
The Supreme Court unanimously held that Pte Hewett and Pte Ellis were within the UK's jurisdiction for the purposes of the Convention at the time of their deaths.
uksc-2015-0214: B is a British national now aged 7.
The Respondent is B's biological mother.
The Appellant is a British national of Indian ethnicity.
The Appellant and the Respondent were previously in a same sex relationship.
The couple lived in England and set up home together.
The couple never became civil partners.
The couple received IUI treatment as a couple.
The Respondent gave birth to B in April 2008.
The Respondent undertook most of B's care.
The Appellant also helped care for B and took her out on weekends.
The couple's relationship broke down acrimoniously in December 2011.
The Appellant left the family home in December 2011.
The Respondent progressively reduced the Appellant's contact with B over the next two years.
The Appellant objected to the reduction in contact and suggested mediation.
The Respondent decided to move with B to Pakistan.
The Respondent moved to Pakistan with B on 3 February 2014.
The Appellant did not consent to B's removal to Pakistan.
B's removal to Pakistan was lawful.
The Appellant applied for orders under the Children Act 1989 on 13 February 2014.
The Appellant's application depended on showing B was habitually resident in England on 13 February 2014.
The Appellant also applied for orders under the court's inherent jurisdiction to have B made a ward of court and returned to England.
Hogg J held that the English court had no jurisdiction over the Appellant's 1989 Act application.
Hogg J also held that the inherent jurisdiction should only be exercised in dire and exceptional circumstances.
The Court of Appeal dismissed the Appellant's appeal.
The Appellant appeals to the Supreme Court on both applications.
The Supreme Court allows the appeal on the Appellant's 1989 Act application.
The Supreme Court decision was by a majority of 3:2.
Lord Clarke and Lord Sumption dissented in the Supreme Court decision.
Lord Wilson gives the lead judgment in the Supreme Court.
Lord Wilson states that the English concept of habitual residence should be governed by the CJEU criterion.
The CJEU criterion focuses on the child's situation and parental intention as one factor.
Lord Wilson identifies two points from the CJEU jurisprudence relevant to losing habitual residence.
The first point is that courts should follow the interpretation that best serves the child's interests.
The second point is that it is exceptional for a child to have no habitual residence.
Lord Wilson concludes that it is highly unlikely for a child to be left without a habitual residence.
Lord Brandons observation in In re J is no longer considered correct.
Hogg J's reliance on Lord Brandons observation was an error.
Lord Wilson states the correct question is whether B had achieved the requisite degree of disengagement from her English environment.
Lord Wilson concludes that B had not achieved the degree of disengagement by 13 February 2014.
Lord Wilson concludes that B retained habitual residence in England on 13 February 2014.
The Appellant's application under the 1989 Act can proceed to substantive determination.
Lord Sumption (dissenting) considers Hogg J made no error of law.
Lord Sumption considers Hogg J was entitled to find that B lost her habitual residence on 3 February 2014.
Lord Clarke agrees with Lord Sumption's view.
Lady Hale and Lord Toulson observe that the inherent jurisdiction is not confined to exceptional circumstances.
Lady Hale and Lord Toulson consider the jurisdiction could have been exercised if B required protection.
Lord Wilson agrees with Lady Hale and Lord Toulson but leaves open whether the inherent jurisdiction should have been exercised.
Lord Sumption (dissenting) considers the inherent jurisdiction should be reserved for exceptional cases.
Lord Sumption considers the jurisdiction could not have been exercised in this case.
Lord Clarke agrees that the inherent jurisdiction should not be used on the facts of this case.
uksc-2009-0180: The appeal concerns whether UK courts must consider the proportionality of evicting an occupier from their home under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
Most residential occupiers of local authority properties are secure tenants under Part IV of the Housing Act 1985.
Secure tenants under the 1985 Act can only be evicted pursuant to the grounds in section 84 of that Act.
The Anti Social Behaviour Act 2003 allows courts to remove security of tenure by making a demotion order.
A demoted tenancy lasts for one year and reverts to a secure tenancy unless possession proceedings are initiated within that year.
Section 143D(2) of the Housing Act 1996 requires the court to make an order for possession unless it determines that the procedure under sections 143E and 143F has not been followed.
Sections 143E and 143F require the landlord to serve a notice to the tenant, including reasons for seeking possession, and to conduct a review if requested.
Mr Pinnock is a demoted tenant who contests a possession order made against him under section 143D.
The possession order was based on incidents of anti-social behaviour by Mr Pinnock's family members.
The Supreme Court concluded that the possession order was proportionate and should be upheld under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
uksc-2010-0106: The appeal concerns the permissibility of excluding a claimant and their representatives from certain employment tribunal proceedings on grounds of national security.
The procedure in question is known as a closed material procedure.
Mr Tariq was employed as an immigration officer with the Home Office until 2006.
Mr Tariq was suspended and his security clearance withdrawn in 2006.
The background for these decisions was the arrest of Mr Tariq's brother and cousin during a terrorist plot investigation.
Mr Tariq's cousin was convicted in 2008 of offences related to the suspected terrorist plot.
No information suggested that Mr Tariq was involved in any terrorism plot.
Mr Tariq claimed direct and indirect discrimination on grounds of race and religion in employment tribunal proceedings.
The Employment Tribunal ordered a closed material procedure, excluding Mr Tariq and his representatives from certain proceedings.
The Supreme Court held that a closed material procedure is compatible with Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights and EU law.
uksc-2012-0143: Mr OBrien was investigated in 2009 for involvement in a large scale boiler room fraud scheme.
A restraint order under section 41 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 was issued against Mr OBrien on 24 September 2009.
The restraint order required Mr OBrien to disclose his assets and return to England and Wales within 21 days.
The restraint order included a penal notice warning Mr OBrien of potential contempt of court if he disobeyed the order.
Mr OBrien disobeyed the restraint order and fled to the United States.
The Common Serjeant found Mr OBrien in contempt and issued a bench warrant for his arrest on 18 December 2009.
The Serious Fraud Office sought Mr OBrien's extradition to face charges related to the boiler room fraud.
Mr OBrien consented to his extradition on 8 October 2010.
The SFO applied to set aside the bench warrant, which was granted on 18 November 2010.
Mr OBrien was returned to the UK on 2 December 2010 and was arrested and charged with various fraud offences.
uksc-2009-0022: Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi is a Zimbabwean national.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi entered the UK lawfully but remained after his leave to remain expired.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was convicted of assault and sexual assault in 2005.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was sentenced to one year of imprisonment and ordered to be registered as a sex offender for five years.
A deportation order was made against Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi on 24 August 2007.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was detained under paragraph 2(2) of Schedule 3 to the Immigration Act 1971 prior to the deportation order.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was detained under paragraph 2(3) of Schedule 3 to the Immigration Act 1971 after the deportation order.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was detained for a total of 27 months until 13 June 2008.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was not released from detention because he has not yet been returned to Zimbabwe.
The Respondent had a policy requiring detention reviews to be conducted at regular intervals.
The Respondent failed to conduct the required number of detention reviews for Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi.
Only six of the required detention reviews for Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi were conducted by officials of the required seniority.
Two of the required detention reviews for Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi were flawed by material errors of fact.
The Supreme Court held that Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi's detention was unlawful for the periods in respect of which no review was carried out.
The Supreme Court held that Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi has a claim in tort for false imprisonment.
The Supreme Court rejected the argument that procedural requirements do not affect the legality of detention.
The policy was sufficiently closely related to the authority to detain to qualify the Secretary of State's discretion.
The Court held that the failure to conduct required reviews resulted in unlawful detention.
The Court held that false imprisonment is actionable in itself without proof of loss or damage.
The amount of damages will depend on whether the claimant would have been released had proper reviews been conducted.
uksc-2013-0161: Ms Mirga was born in Poland.
Ms Mirga moved back to the UK in 2004.
The benefit rights of Polish nationals in the UK were governed by the A8 Regulations.
Ms Mirga worked for seven months under the A8 Regulations.
Ms Mirga did three months of unregistered work after becoming pregnant.
Ms Mirga claimed income support in August 2006.
The Secretary of State refused Ms Mirga's income support claim.
The First tier Tribunal upheld the Secretary of State's decision.
Mr Samin was born in Iraq in 1960.
Mr Samin came to the UK in December 2005 and has lived there alone.
uksc-2013-0057: The appeal is from Guernsey, which does not have an equivalent of the 2006 Act.
The common laws of England and Guernsey are considered identical in this area.
The principal issue is whether the reasoning in Barker still applies in Guernsey.
The second principal issue is whether an employer's liability insurer covering only part of the exposure period is liable for a pro rata part of the employer's liability.
The third principal issue is whether an insurer is liable for the whole of the employer's liability if Barker does not apply.
The fourth principal issue is whether the insurer has pro rata rights to contribution from other insurers or the employer.
Mr Carr was negligently exposed to asbestos dust by his employer from 1961 to 1988.
Mr Carr later contracted mesothelioma and died as a result.
Mr Carr sued the Respondent and recovered compensation of 250,000 damages and interest.
The trial judge ordered Zurich to meet 22.08% of the compensation but 100% of the defence costs.
The Supreme Court unanimously held that the common law rule in Barker continues to apply in Guernsey.
The Supreme Court dismissed Zurich's appeal in relation to defence costs.
The Supreme Court stated its opinion on other issues, including contribution rights.
The majority concluded that Zurich would have been liable for the full compensation if Guernsey had the 2006 Act.
The majority held that Zurich has equitable rights to pro rata contribution from other insurers or the employer.
The minority considered that Zurich is only liable for 22.08% of the full loss.
The Court agreed that defence costs were incurred with insurers' consent and were necessary for the claim.
The Court applied the rule in Fairchild, as applied in Trigger, to mesothelioma cases.
The majority considered that if IEG had been insolvent, Mr Carr could have looked to Zurich for full loss.
uksc-2012-0025: Lord Reed questioned whether the approach taken by the courts below and the parties' printed cases was correct.
Lord Reed concluded that the case concerns a continuing representation capable of remaining in effect until the contract is concluded.
The representation in the critical email was of a continuing nature while Mr Erskine remained the prospective contracting party.
A representation may continue to be asserted and have a causative effect even if the contracting parties are not the original representor and representee.
The parties' conduct suggests they proceeded with negotiations on the basis that the representation continued to be asserted after the identity of the prospective contracting party changed.
The representation could continue to have a causative effect, inducing the conclusion of the contract.
If a representation continues to be made until the contract is concluded, the risk of harm from reliance on it may be foreseeable.
The representor may assume responsibility for the accuracy of the representation towards the contracting party who relied on it, even if they are not the original representee.
A representation made by a company's agent prior to the commencement of their agency may have the same effect if the person to whom it is addressed becomes the agent of the contracting party.
The respondents continued and concluded negotiations with Cramaso without withdrawing the representation made to Mr Erskine, implicitly asserting its accuracy to Cramaso.
uksc-2014-0087: The Claimant entered the Respondent's premises on 15 March 2008 in Small Heath, Birmingham.
The premises included a petrol station and a kiosk where customers pay for purchases.
The Claimant parked his car and entered the kiosk to ask about printing documents from a USB stick.
Mr Amjid Khan was employed by the Respondent to maintain the petrol pumps and kiosk and to serve customers.
Mr Khan refused the Claimant's request in a rude manner.
The Claimant protested Mr Khan's refusal.
Mr Khan responded with foul, racist, and threatening language and ordered the Claimant to leave.
The Claimant returned to his car, followed by Mr Khan.
Mr Khan punched the Claimant on the left temple before he could drive off.
The Claimant was subjected to a serious attack by Mr Khan after he got out of his car.
uksc-2014-0094: The patient was clinically asymptomatic at the time of his initial request for a heart screen.
The patient requested a heart screen from his GP on 30 May 2008.
The GP referred the patient for an electrocardiogram (ECG) test in July 2008.
The ECG test reported negative for ischaemic heart disease.
No further action was taken following the negative ECG test.
The patient complained of chest pain to a locum doctor on 10 December 2008.
The GP referred the patient to a chest pain clinic 5 days after the chest pain complaint.
The chest pain clinic declined to see the patient due to his earlier negative test.
The clinic sent a report to the practice on 20 December 2008, which was not marked urgent or reviewed.
The patient attended the practice again on 6 January 2009 to inquire about an appointment.
The GP referred the patient for another ECG, but the patient died of a myocardial infarction later that day.
The patient's widow complained to the Northern Ireland Commissioner for Complaints.
The Commissioner held that the practice had failed to provide a reasonable level of care and treatment.
The Commissioner recommended that the GP make a payment of £10,000 to the widow.
The GP refused to make the payment.
The Commissioner indicated he would lay a special report before the Northern Ireland Assembly.
The Commissioner's recommendation was upheld at first instance but quashed by the Court of Appeal.
The Commissioner appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
The Supreme Court held that the Commissioner had no power to recommend a monetary payment against a private individual.
The Commissioner's power to investigate was derived from Article 8 of the 1996 Order.
The Commissioner may not investigate cases where the complainant has a legal remedy unless it is unreasonable to expect them to use it.
The widow had a legal remedy but the Commissioner proceeded with the investigation.
The Commissioner could not recommend a payment after proceeding with the investigation.
The Commissioner does not have the power to make a special report in default of payment.
The Commissioner's relationship with the legislature differs from that of other statutory ombudsmen.
The Commissioner is not an officer of the legislature.
The Commissioner has no powers of compulsion.
The Commissioner has limited powers to use information for enforcement.
Article 19 of the 1996 Order deals with annual reports, not individual case reports.
Lord Sumption gave the judgment, with which the other justices agreed.
The Commissioner's monetary recommendation lacked a rational explanation or calculation.
The Commissioner did not identify the precise failings for which the payment was recommended.
uksc-2012-0181: AA was born in Somalia on 21 August 1994.
AA's father was killed in the mid 1990s.
AA became separated from her mother and siblings during the fighting in Somalia.
AA went to live with her brother-in-law, Mohamed, around the end of 2002.
Mohamed had a daughter named Fadima and a step-daughter named Amaani.
Mohamed took AA into his family home under the Islamic legal procedure known as Kafala.
Mohamed left Somalia and arrived in the UK in November 2007.
Mohamed was granted asylum in the UK on 21 July 2008.
The three girls, AA, Fadima, and Amaani, were left with a maternal aunt in Mogadishu.
Entry clearance was granted to Fadima and Amaani, who arrived in the UK in January 2010.
AA's entry clearance was refused and she remained in Addis Ababa pending her appeal.
AA's appeal was heard in the First tier Tribunal (FTT) on 3 September 2010.
The FTT allowed AA's appeal under paragraph 352D and article 8 ECHR.
The Secretary of State appealed the FTT's decision on paragraph 352D.
The Upper Tribunal allowed the Secretary of State's appeal on paragraph 352D.
The Court of Appeal confirmed the Upper Tribunal's decision on 2 May 2012.
AA was granted entry clearance on 14 May 2012 and arrived in the UK on 4 June 2012.
AA appealed to the Supreme Court regarding paragraph 352D of the Immigration Rules.
The Supreme Court dismissed AA's appeal.
Lord Carnwath gave the lead judgment, with which other justices agreed.
The Supreme Court held that paragraph 352D does not cover AA's case.
The definition of adoptive parent in paragraph 6 is more restricted than Kafala.
Paragraph 309A does not cover AA's case.
International instruments call for a broad approach to protecting children's interests.
The best interests principle is recognized by domestic and international law.
There is no specific international obligation covering AA's position.
AA's treatment under the rules is less favorable than her siblings.
The Secretary of State is obliged to act in conformity with the Convention when exercising discretion.
uksc-2012-0162: The case involves appeals concerning liability to pay National Insurance Contributions (NICs).
The case focuses on the interpretation of the phrase "earnings" in section 6(1) of the Social Security Contributions and Benefits Act 1992.
The phrase in question relates to payments made to or for the benefit of an earner.
The case involves a Funded Unapproved Retirement Benefits Scheme set up by FML.
The scheme was established by trust deed on 11 April 2002.
The scheme provides benefits to employees and directors upon retirement or death.
Mr McHugh became a member of the scheme on 11 April 2002.
Mr McHugh requested that his wife be the beneficiary in the event of his death.
FML made an initial cash contribution of £1,000 and transferred Treasury Stock valued at £162,000 to the scheme.
Mr McHugh has received no relevant benefits from the scheme.
uksc-2009-0152: The Respondent was vaccinated on 3 November 1992 with a vaccine manufactured in France by Aventis Pasteur SA (APSA).
On 18 September 1992, APSA sent a consignment of the vaccine, including the Product, to its subsidiary APMSD in England.
APMSD acted as a United Kingdom distributor for APSA's products.
APMSD received the consignment on 22 September 1992 and sold part of it, including the Product, on an unknown date.
The Product was eventually used to vaccinate the Respondent.
On 1 August 2001, the Respondent began proceedings under section 2 of the Consumer Protection Act 1987 against APMSD.
On 16 October 2002, the Respondent issued separate proceedings against APSA also under section 2 of the CPA.
APSA defended the action by relying on section 11(3) of the Limitation Act 1980 and Article 11 of the Council Directive 85/374/EEC.
Article 11 provides a ten-year time limit for initiating proceedings against the producer of a product.
The Respondent sought an order to substitute APSA for APMSD as defendant in the proceedings against APMSD.
uksc-2012-0179: The United Kingdom failed to secure compliance with nitrogen dioxide limits set by EU law since 2010.
The Supreme Court referred questions to the CJEU regarding the interpretation of Directive 2008/50/EC.
Article 13 of the Directive sets limit values for nitrogen dioxide that must not be exceeded from 1 January 2010.
Article 22 allows a member state to apply for a postponement of the compliance deadline under certain conditions.
Article 23 requires member states to prepare air quality plans for areas exceeding the nitrogen dioxide limits.
Air quality plans under Article 23 must include measures to limit transport emissions.
The UK produced air quality plans in 2011 predicting compliance would not be achieved until 2025.
The Secretary of State did not apply for postponement under Article 22 for some non-compliant zones.
The Supreme Court ordered the UK government to submit new air quality plans to the European Commission by 31 December 2015.
The CJEU judgment confirmed that the UK's failure to comply with Article 13 constitutes a serious breach of EU law.
uksc-2017-0096: Mr Holden accidentally set fire to his car while repairing it at Phoenix Engineering.
The fire caused £2 million in damage to Phoenix and its neighbors' premises.
Phoenix's insurer, Axa, paid out the claim and agreed not to pursue Mr Holden personally.
Axa claims Mr Holden is covered by his car insurance policy's third party liability cover.
Churchill, Mr Holden's car insurance provider, disputes that he is covered under the policy.
Clause 1a of the policy covers legal responsibility if there is an accident in the vehicle involving injury or damage to property.
The policy includes a certificate stating it meets the requirements of the Road Traffic Act 1988.
Under the Road Traffic Act 1988, car insurance must cover liability for damage to property caused by or arising out of the use of a vehicle on a road or public place.
The High Court ruled that the policy did not cover Mr Holden's accident because it arose from the negligent repair, not the use of the car.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed Mr Holden's appeal, finding the policy must be interpreted to meet the statutory requirements of the Road Traffic Act.
uksc-2018-0132: The compensation scheme was established in 1999 by the Department for Trade and Industry.
The scheme provided compensation for miners with vibration white finger (VWF) due to vibration exposure.
Compensation included General Damages for pain, suffering, and loss of amenity.
Compensation also included Special Damages for financial losses like loss of earnings.
The scheme included a services award for assistance with domestic tasks.
The scheme used a presumption based on the severity of VWF for services awards.
Mr Arthur Watkins worked as a miner for British Coal from 1964 to 1985.
Mr Watkins developed VWF by the early 1980s.
Mr Watkins sought a services award under the scheme in 2003.
Mr Watkins accepted a tariff award for General Damages in 2003 as a full and final settlement.
uksc-2018-0131: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc filed patents for a new type of genetically modified mouse in 2001.
The hybrid mouse combines a section of the mouse's genetic material with a section of human genetic material.
The resulting mouse produces antibodies suitable for medical treatment in humans.
The hybrid mice do not cause immunological sickness in the mouse.
Combining a human variable region with a mouse constant region was a major scientific contribution.
Hybrid mice developed by Regeneron had medical uses, including in antibody therapies against coronavirus.
Regeneron sued Kymab Ltd in 2013 for patent infringement.
Kymab produced genetically modified mice with a similar genetic structure to Regeneron's mice.
Kymab argued Regeneron's 2001 patents were invalid due to insufficient detail.
The Supreme Court ruled that Regeneron's patents were invalid for insufficiency.
uksc-2020-0042: The Airports National Policy Statement (ANPS) is the national policy framework governing the construction of a third runway at Heathrow Airport.
Future applications for development consent to build the third runway will be considered against the ANPS.
The ANPS does not grant development consent in its own right.
Successive governments have considered the need for increased airport capacity in the South East of England.
The Secretary of State for Transport declared the Government accepted the case for airport expansion in 2015.
The North West Runway (NWR) scheme was announced as the preferred scheme in October 2016.
The UK signed the Paris Agreement on 22 April 2016.
The UK ratified the Paris Agreement on 17 November 2016.
The Paris Agreement sets targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and temperature increases from global warming.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal against the designation of the ANPS.
uksc-2011-0089: Both appeals raise issues about the rule in Hastings Bass.
The rule in Hastings Bass concerns trustees who make decisions without proper consideration of relevant matters.
The appeal in Pitt raises issues about the court's jurisdiction to set aside a voluntary disposition on the ground of mistake.
In 1985, Mr Mark Futter made two settlements.
Initially, both settlements had non-resident trustees.
In 2004, Mr Futter and Mr Cutbill were appointed as resident trustees.
In 2008, Mr Futter and Mr Cutbill distributed the capital of the first settlement to Mr Futter.
In 2008, Mr Futter and Mr Cutbill distributed 36,000 from the second settlement to Mr Futter's three children.
The trustees overlooked the effect of section 2(4) of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992.
Mr Futter and Mr Cutbill applied to have the deeds of enlargement and advancement declared void.
In 1990, Mr Derek Pitt suffered serious head injuries resulting in mental incapacity.
Mr Pitt's claim for damages was compromised by a court-approved settlement in 1994.
The settlement was structured as a discretionary settlement.
The Derek Pitt Special Needs Trust was established in 1994.
The SNT could have been established without inheritance tax liability.
The report from Frankel Topping made no reference to inheritance tax.
Mr Pitt died in 2007.
His personal representatives commenced proceedings to have the SNT set aside.
The deputy judge ordered the SNT set aside based on the rule in Hastings Bass.
The deputy judge indicated that a mistake as to consequences was not sufficient for rescission.
The Revenues appealed against the decisions in the Court of Appeal.
Lloyd LJ allowed the appeals, finding the rule in Hastings Bass not applicable.
Lloyd LJ dismissed Mrs Pitt's appeal based on mistake.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal in Futter.
The Supreme Court allowed the appeal in Pitt on the ground of mistake.
The Supreme Court set aside the SNT.
Lord Walker gave the judgment, with which the other justices agreed.
The rule in Hastings Bass depends on breach of duty in the performance of trustees' powers.
The rule in Hastings Bass is centered on the failure of trustees to perform their decision-making function.
The courts have flexibility in applying the rule in Hastings Bass.
The rule in Hastings Bass applies only if trustees' inadequate deliberation amounts to a breach of fiduciary duty.
The court may not always set aside a trustee's decision if there is a breach of duty.
Trustees should not be held strictly liable for following apparently competent professional advice.
The rule in Hastings Bass must balance protecting beneficiaries against aberrant conduct with legal certainty.
Rescission on the ground of mistake requires a causative mistake of sufficient gravity.
A mistake must be about the legal character or nature of a transaction or a basic fact or law.
Consequences, including tax consequences, are relevant to the gravity of a mistake.
A mistake is distinct from mere ignorance, inadvertence, or misprediction.
Mere ignorance, even if causative, is insufficient for rescission.
The court must evaluate the injustice of leaving a mistaken disposition uncorrected.
Mrs Pitt had an incorrect belief that the SNT had no adverse tax effects.
The SNT could have been established without artificiality or abuse of statutory relief.
The SNT was the sort of trust Parliament intended to grant relief.
uksc-2011-0011: The HJ (Iran) principle was established in a previous court decision.
The principle was applied to a gay man seeking asylum from Iran.
The country guidance for Zimbabwe indicates a campaign of persecution by militias.
The militias target individuals who cannot demonstrate support for Zanu PF.
The regime uses methods like requiring a Zanu PF card to establish loyalty.
Failure to demonstrate loyalty is considered support for the opposition.
The regime has unleashed a campaign of violence, murder, and displacement.
RT, SM, and AM were asylum seekers from Zimbabwe who had their claims refused.
The Court of Appeal allowed their appeals based on the HJ (Iran) principle.
The Supreme Court dismissed the Home Secretary's appeals in the cases of RT, SM, and AM.
uksc-2011-0244: The Financial Services Authority (FSA) applied for a freezing injunction against Sinaloa Gold and PH Capital Invest on 20 December 2010.
The FSA alleged that both companies were promoting the sale of shares without proper authorisation and an approved prospectus.
The FSA also alleged that PH Capital Invest had breached FSMA in various other respects.
Schedule B to the injunction stated that the FSA gave no cross undertaking in damages.
Under Schedule B, the FSA undertook to cover both costs and losses incurred by third parties as a result of the injunction.
The undertaking in respect of third party losses was inadvertent.
The FSA applied to have the undertaking in respect of third party losses removed.
Barclays, which had six bank accounts with Sinaloa Gold plc, intervened to oppose the application to remove the undertaking.
The High Court refused the application to have the undertaking removed.
The Court of Appeal reversed the High Court's decision and preserved the undertaking in respect of third party costs but eliminated the undertaking in respect of third party losses.
uksc-2014-0159: In June 2006, Hastings Borough Council restricted public access to Hastings Pier due to serious structural defects.
Manolete Partners PLC pursued a compensation claim against the Council for business losses caused by the pier closure.
Manolete brought the claim as an assignee of Stylus Sports Ltd, which later went into liquidation.
Stylus leased two units from Ravenclaw Investments Incorporated on the Hastings Pier.
Stylus operated a bingo hall and amusement arcade at the pier.
Two years before the pier closure, Stylus commissioned a structural engineering survey that identified urgent repairs needed.
Ravenclaw, the landlord, failed to take action to repair the pier's structural defects.
The Council also failed to act on the structural defects, and the pier remained open to the public.
In April 2006, a section of tension cord fell from the pier, prompting the Council to seek urgent action.
The Council exercised its emergency powers under section 78 of the 1984 Act in June 2006 to restrict pier access.
uksc-2016-0080: Both PJS and YMA are well known individuals in the entertainment business.
PJS and YMA have two young children.
Between 2009 and 2011, PJS had a sexual relationship with AB.
On one occasion, PJS had a sexual relationship with both AB and CD.
In January 2016, the editor of the Sun on Sunday newspaper proposed to publish AB's account of the relationship.
PJS claimed that the publication would breach his rights to privacy and confidentiality under Article 8 of the ECHR.
PJS applied for an interim injunction to restrain the publication pending the trial of his claim.
The High Court refused PJS's application for an interim injunction, but the Court of Appeal granted it.
The Supreme Court granted permission to appeal and restored the interim injunction.
uksc-2010-0201: Mr Seldon joined the law firm in 1971 and became an equity partner in 1972.
In 2005, Mr Seldon and other partners adopted a partnership deed with a mandatory retirement age of 65.
Mr Seldon reached the age of 65 on 15 January 2006.
Mr Seldon requested an extension of his tenure after reaching the mandatory retirement age.
The other partners rejected Mr Seldon's request, citing no sufficient business need.
The partners offered Mr Seldon an ex gratia payment of £30,000.
The Employment Equality (Age) Regulations 2006 came into force in October 2006.
Mr Seldon informed the partners he was considering his rights under the Age Regulations.
The partners withdrew their offer of an ex gratia payment after Mr Seldon mentioned his legal rights.
Mr Seldon ceased to be a partner in the firm on 31 December 2006.
uksc-2016-0048: DD was born in 2006 in Romania to Romanian parents who met while working in England.
The family returned to England after DD was born.
The parents separated in 2007, and DD has lived in England since then in the care of his mother.
The father returned to Romania in 2009 but has maintained a significant relationship with his son.
The father commenced divorce and custody proceedings in Romania in 2007.
The Romanian Court of Appeal issued a decision in November 2013 stating that DD should live with his father.
The father applied for the recognition and enforcement of the custody order in the English court in February 2014.
These proceedings are governed by the Brussels II (Revised) Regulation (BIIR).
The English High Court refused the father's application in July 2014 under Article 23(b) BIIR.
The Supreme Court ruled that it does not have jurisdiction to hear the father's appeal against the enforcement of the custody order.
uksc-2016-0004: The appellant was in the care of the respondent local authority from the age of seven to eighteen.
The local authority placed the appellant in foster care with Mr and Mrs A between March 1985 and March 1986.
The local authority placed the appellant in foster care with Mr and Mrs B between October 1987 and February 1988.
The appellant was physically and emotionally abused by Mrs A.
The appellant was sexually abused by Mr B.
The case was based on the argument that the local authority were not negligent in selecting or supervising the foster parents.
The case was based on the argument that the local authority were liable for the abuse due to a non-delegable duty or vicarious liability.
The claim was dismissed by the High Court and the Court of Appeal.
The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, finding the local authority vicariously liable for the abuse by the foster parents.
The Supreme Court rejected the argument that the local authority were liable due to a non-delegable duty.
uksc-2011-0117: Section 175 of the Housing Act 1996 defines a person as homeless if they have no accommodation available for occupation in the United Kingdom or elsewhere.

Section 176 of the Housing Act 1996 states that accommodation is available for occupation only if it is available for the person and any other person who normally resides with them as a family member.
The phrase "available for his occupation" is relevant to determining both homelessness and the duties of local housing authorities under the Housing Act 1996.
In 2004, Camden London Borough Council accepted a duty under the Housing Act 1996 to provide accommodation to Ms Sharif, her father, and her sister.
Ms Sharif, her father, and her sister were initially accommodated in a hostel and later moved to a three-bedroom house owned by a private sector landlord.
In 2009, the Council offered Ms Sharif, her father, and her sister two separate units in a block of flats in North London.
Each unit offered to Ms Sharif's family included a single bed sitting room with cooking facilities and a bathroom.
Ms Sharif refused the offer, arguing that her father's medical condition required them to live in the same unit of accommodation.
The Council's reviewing officer concluded that the offered accommodation was suitable, but Ms Sharif appealed the decision.

The Supreme Court held that section 176 of the Housing Act 1996 does not prevent local authorities from offering a homeless family two separate units of accommodation if they enable the family to live together in practical terms.
uksc-2010-0154: The Appellant is a UK company based near Aberdeen and is a subsidiary of Halliburton Inc., a US corporation.
Mr Ravat is a British citizen who lived in Preston, Lancashire.
Mr Ravat was employed by the Appellant from April 1990 until May 2006.
Mr Ravat was made redundant in May 2006 and claims he was unfairly dismissed.
At the time of his dismissal, Mr Ravat was working in Libya.
Mr Ravat's employment documentation described him as a UK commuter.
Mr Ravat worked 28 consecutive days in Libya, followed by 28 consecutive days off in Preston.
Mr Ravat was job sharing, working back to back with another employee.
Mr Ravat's salary was paid in Sterling to a UK bank account, and he paid income tax and national insurance on the PAYE basis.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the Appellant's appeal and remitted the case to the employment tribunal to consider the merits of Mr Ravat's unfair dismissal claim.
uksc-2015-0216: The Children and Young People (Scotland) Act 2014 establishes a named person service for all children and young people in Scotland.
The named person service aims to shift from post-risk intervention to early intervention for promoting wellbeing.
The named person service requires statutory bodies to work collaboratively and share information to support wellbeing.
The named person service includes advising, informing, or supporting children and their parents.
The named person service helps children and their parents access services or support.
The named person service discusses or raises matters about children with service providers or relevant authorities.
The authority responsible for the named person service depends on the age and circumstances of the child.
Part 4 of the 2014 Act outlines powers and duties relating to information sharing between service providers and the named person provider.
The named person service has a power of disclosure when it considers it necessary or expedient for the exercise of named person functions.
The named person service cannot disclose information in breach of a prohibition or restriction under an enactment.
uksc-2012-0109: Mr and Mrs Stott decided to take a holiday in Zante, Greece, in September 2008.
Mr Stott is paralysed from the shoulders down and a permanent wheelchair user.
Mr Stott has double incontinence and uses a catheter.
Mr Stott depends on his wife to manage his incontinence, help him to eat, and change his sitting position when travelling by air.
Mr Stott booked return flights with Thomas Cook Tour Operators Ltd, a tour operator and air carrier.
Mr Stott telephoned Thomas Cook's helpline twice, informing them that he had paid to be seated with his wife, and was assured that this would happen.
On arrival at check in for the return journey, Mr and Mrs Stott were told that they would not be seated together.
Mr Stott had difficulties in boarding the aircraft, and was not sufficiently assisted by Thomas Cook staff.
Mr Stott was eventually helped into his seat, with his wife sitting behind him.
The Court of Appeal held that the Montreal Convention prevented the award of damages for injury to feelings.
uksc-2017-0073: Nottingham City Council is the licensing authority for houses in multiple occupation (HMOs) in its area under Part 2 of the Housing Act 2004.
The appeal concerns two HMOs owned by Trevor Parr Associates Ltd.
Dominic Parr is the managing director of Trevor Parr Associates Ltd and the manager of the two HMOs.
The Housing Act 2004 requires HMOs to be licensed by the local housing authority.
The local housing authority can grant an HMO licence if it is satisfied that the house is reasonably suitable for occupation.
The appellant issued guidance stating that the minimum space provision for bedrooms in single occupation in HMOs is eight square metres.
44, Rothesay Avenue and 50, Bute Avenue are both used for letting to students.
Both HMOs have attic bedrooms with usable living space below eight square metres.
The appellant granted HMO licences with conditions prohibiting the use of the attic bedrooms for sleeping.
The First tier Tribunal deleted the conditions imposed by the appellant in both cases.
uksc-2013-0006: On 6 December 2010, the Crown Prosecution Service applied for restraint orders under section 41 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 against two individuals.
The Crown Prosecution Service also sought restraint and receivership orders against Eastenders Group.
Eastenders Group was a holding company for several trading cash and carry retail outlets.
The CPS sought to investigate a suspected fraud on HMRC through Eastenders Group companies.
A POCA restraint order prevents named persons from dealing with their assets until the order is discharged.
A receivership order appoints a receiver to manage the assets of the company subject to the restraint order.
Mr Barnes was appointed as the receiver of Eastenders Group under an agreement with the CPS.
The letter of agreement between the CPS and Mr Barnes stated that Mr Barnes would be remunerated from Eastenders Group property.
The Crown Court judge refused to discharge the orders against Eastenders Group on 23 December 2010.
The Court of Appeal quashed the orders, stating there was no good arguable case that the Group's assets were the individuals' assets.
The Court of Appeal also noted that 95% of Eastenders Group's business was demonstrably legitimate.
During the receivership, the receiver incurred costs and expenses totaling £772,547.
The receiver applied to the Crown Court for permission to draw his remuneration and expenses from Eastenders Group assets.
Underhill J refused the application, citing a breach of the Group's right to peaceful enjoyment of its possessions under Article 1 of Protocol 1 to the ECHR.
The CPS appealed the decision to the Court of Appeal.
The majority of the Court of Appeal upheld Underhill J's decision that the Group's A1P1 rights would be infringed by an order allowing the receiver to draw remuneration from its assets.
Laws LJ dissented and would have allowed the receiver to draw remuneration from Eastenders Group assets.
The Court of Appeal unanimously held there was no basis under POCA or the HRA 1998 for the CPS to pay the receiver's expenses.
The receiver appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the receiver's appeal against the Court of Appeal's refusal to have the CPS pay the receiver's remuneration and expenses.
uksc-2014-0073: The United States of America closed a watercraft repair centre in Hampshire in 2006.
Mrs Nolan was employed at the closed watercraft repair centre by the appellant.
Mrs Nolan was dismissed for redundancy the day before the watercraft repair centre closed.
Mrs Nolan claimed the appellant failed to consult with any employee representative before her dismissal.
The appellant denied having a duty to consult with employee representatives.
Mrs Nolan brought Employment Tribunal proceedings under TULCRA as amended by the 1995 Regulations.
TULCRA originally extended a right to consultation to employees of public administrative bodies.
TULCRA was amended in 1995 to require employee representatives for consultation in all covered situations.
The Supreme Court dismissed the USA's appeal on three grounds, with a majority decision of 4:1.
The case was remitted to the Court of Appeal for further determination of the UK Coal Mining/Fujitsu issues.
uksc-2009-0125: The original maximum sentence for driving while disqualified under the Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988 was six months imprisonment or a fine.
The maximum sentence for driving while disqualified when prosecuted on indictment was 12 months imprisonment or a fine.
The Criminal Proceedings etc (Reform)(Scotland) Act 2007 increased the maximum sentence for driving while disqualified to 12 months imprisonment when sentenced summarily.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller were each sentenced to more than six months imprisonment for driving while disqualified in summary proceedings.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller challenged their sentences, arguing that the amendment to the 2007 Act was outside the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The High Court of Justiciary dismissed the appeals, stating that the amendment to the sentencing powers was within the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, holding that the provision in question was within the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The Supreme Court's majority judgment applied the rules in sections 29 and Part 1 of Schedule 4 of the Scotland Act 1998 to determine legislative competence.
The purpose of Section 45 of the 2007 Act was to reform summary justice by reducing pressure on higher courts.
The Supreme Court concluded that the rule modified by Section 45 was a rule of Scots criminal procedure, not a reserved matter.
uksc-2013-0273: Section 28 of the Housing Act 1988 sets out the method for calculating damages for unlawful eviction.
Section 27 of the Housing Act 1988 provides the right to claim damages for unlawful eviction.
The Housing Act 1988 includes safeguards to prevent unscrupulous landlords from evicting tenants with protected tenancies.
Mr Loveridge lived in the downstairs flat at 19 Moresby Walk from November 2002.
Both flats at 19 Moresby Walk were owned by the London Borough of Lambeth and let under secure tenancies.
Mr Loveridge was unlawfully evicted by Lambeth between July and December 2009.
Lambeth changed the locks on Mr Loveridge's flat and cleared his possessions, believing he had died.
Mr Loveridge's surveyor calculated the difference in value between two valuations of Lambeth's interest in 19 Moresby Walk as £90,500.
Lambeth's surveyor assumed that both flats were subject to assured tenancies for the purpose of valuation.
The Supreme Court restored the original damages award of £90,500 under section 28 of the Housing Act 1988.
uksc-2018-0140: DN is a Rwandan national who was granted refugee status in the UK on 26 October 2000.
DN was convicted in the UK of assisting the unlawful entry of a non-EEA national on 22 January 2007.
DN pleaded guilty to the offence under section 25 of the Immigration Act 1971.
DN was sentenced to 12 months imprisonment for the Immigration Act offence.
DN was sentenced to two months consecutive imprisonment for each of three pecuniary advantage offences.
DN's total sentence was 18 months imprisonment.
The Secretary of State has powers under the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 to order the deportation of persons convicted of serious offences.
Section 72(4)(a) of the 2002 Act presumes a person convicted of an offence specified by the Secretary of State to be a danger to the UK community.
The 2004 Order specified assisting unlawful immigration under section 25 of the 1971 Act as a particularly serious crime.
DN was detained pending deportation following a decision made by the Secretary of State on 2 July 2007.
uksc-2017-0110: The case involves the classification of chicken and pork products from Newby Foods Ltd under EU Regulation No 853/2004.
The appeal concerns whether the products should be classified as mechanically separated meat (MSM) under point 1.14 of Annex I.
Newby Foods Ltd argues that their products should not be classified as MSM.
The Food Standards Agency (FSA) contends that the products should be classified as MSM.
EU Regulation No 853/2004 defines two types of MSM: high pressure and low pressure.
MSM is subject to specific hygiene requirements and cannot count towards food meat content.
MSM produced from lamb and beef bones is prohibited under EU law.
Newby developed a machine to remove residual meat from carcase bones.
Newby's process involves two stages: shearing meat from bones and producing a product similar to minced meat.
Newby's product was previously known as desinewed meat (DSM) and was not recognized as a category in EU law.
uksc-2012-0072: Section 2(6)(e) of the Extradition Act 2003 requires an EAW to include particulars of the sentence(s) imposed.
The requested court uses the sentence details in the EAW to determine if it meets the minimum extradition offence threshold.
Section 65(3)(c) of the Act applies to offences in the requesting state that would be offences in the UK, provided a minimum sentence of four months was imposed.
Many EU states aggregate successive sentences to produce a single sentence, often reducing the total imprisonment period.
Earlier case law allows an EAW to specify the cumulative sentence rather than individual sentences if they meet extradition requirements.
This appeal concerns the situation where an EAW specifies original sentences, but they are later aggregated, reducing the total sentence.
Lukasz Zakrzewski was convicted four times in Poland for offences of dishonesty or violence.
The EAW issued on 24 February 2010 specified the original sentences, not the cumulative one.
The High Court ruled that an EAW must relate to the current operative sentence, not to earlier aggregated sentences.
The Supreme Court unanimously restored the extradition order, finding the EAW was valid despite the aggregation of sentences.
uksc-2015-0063: Ms Janah is a Moroccan national who worked as a domestic worker for Libya's London embassy.
Ms Benkharbouche is a Moroccan national who worked for Sudan's London embassy.
Both Ms Janah and Ms Benkharbouche were dismissed from their employment.
Both Ms Janah and Ms Benkharbouche filed claims in the Employment Tribunal against Libya and Sudan respectively.
Some of the claims were based on EU law.
Some of the claims were based on breach of contract or domestic UK statutes.
The Employment Tribunal dismissed the claims on the basis of state immunity under the State Immunity Act 1978.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal allowed the appeals and found sections of the 1978 Act incompatible with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the Secretary of State's appeal.
The Supreme Court held that sections 4(2)(b) and 16(1)(a) of the 1978 Act are incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights.
uksc-2013-0243: Mrs Sylvie Beghal was stopped by police at East Midlands Airport on 4 January 2011.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was returning from a visit to her husband in Paris, who is a French national in custody on terrorist offences.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was questioned under Paragraph 2 of Schedule 7 of the Terrorism Act 2000.
The questioning was conducted without requiring reasonable suspicion of a past or future offence.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was searched and asked questions about her relationship with her husband and her travel.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal refused to answer most of the questions and was charged with wilful failure to comply.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal pleaded guilty to the charge and received a conditional discharge.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal challenged the Schedule 7 powers on the grounds of breaching her ECHR rights.
The Supreme Court dismissed her appeal by a majority of 4 to 1, with Lord Kerr dissenting.
The Court found that the Schedule 7 powers are proportionate and in accordance with the law under Article 8 ECHR.
uksc-2011-0024: Paragraph 277 of the Immigration Rules was amended in 2008 to raise the minimum age for a spouse or sponsor from 18 to 21.
The amendment to Paragraph 277 was intended to deter forced marriages.
A forced marriage involves at least one party entering the marriage without free and full consent.
Mr Quila applied for a marriage visa before the amendment took effect but was refused due to his wife's age.
By the time Ms Jeffery turned 18, the amendment was in force and the Home Office refused to waive it.
Mr Quila and Ms Jeffery were forced to leave the UK to live in Chile and later Ireland.
Bibi, a Pakistani national, applied to join her husband in the UK but was refused due to both parties being under 21.
The High Court rejected the Respondents' claims for judicial review, but the Court of Appeal ruled the refusal breached Article 8 of the ECHR.
The Supreme Court dismissed the Secretary of State's appeal, finding the refusal to grant marriage visas infringed Article 8 ECHR.
The Secretary of State failed to provide robust evidence that the amendment had a substantial deterrent effect on forced marriages.
uksc-2010-0189: The Wolverhampton City Council granted planning permission for four blocks of student accommodation near an LPG storage site.
Three of the four blocks of student accommodation had been completed.
Work on the fourth block of student accommodation had not commenced.
The Health and Safety Executive applied for an order to revoke or modify the planning permission.
The Council refused the HSE's application without considering revoking permission for the fourth block only.
The HSE brought judicial review proceedings against the Council's decision.
The High Court refused the HSE's claim.
The Court of Appeal allowed the HSE's appeal, finding the Council's decision irrational.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the HSE's appeal regarding the consideration of compensation costs.
The Supreme Court held that a public authority may consider the cost of its actions when exercising a statutory power.
uksc-2013-0083: LGDC sold the hotel and adjoining golf courses to NSL in February 2001.
The sale price recorded in the disposition was 248,100.
LGDC purchased the subjects in November 1994 for just over 2 million.
The value of the subjects at the time of sale was estimated at about 1.8 million.
LGDC went into liquidation in December 2002.
NSL granted a standard security over the subjects in January 2003 in favour of Foxworth Investments Limited.
The liquidator of LGDC, Mr Henderson, began proceedings against NSL in 2003 seeking reduction of the 2001 disposition.
The liquidator obtained a decree by default in 2009 when NSL failed to be represented.
The appellants claim that NSL assumed debts of 1.85m owed by LGDC to Mr Liu and his family.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal by Foxworth and NSL.
uksc-2018-0154: Visa and Mastercard operate open four-party payment card schemes.
Issuers provide debit and/or credit cards to cardholders.
Acquirers provide payment services to merchants.
Scheme operators set the rules of the payment card schemes.
Cardholders contract with issuers for terms including fees, interest rates, and rewards.
Merchants contract with acquirers for payment services, paying a merchant service charge (MSC).
The issuer pays the acquirer, who passes the payment to the merchant less the MSC.
The schemes include a default interchange fee known as the multilateral interchange fee (MIF).
The MIF is typically passed on to merchants through the MSC.
Visa and Mastercard do not receive any part of the MIF or the MSC.
uksc-2011-0260: The Pensions Act 2004 introduced a financial support direction (FSD) regime to protect employees from underfunded occupational pension schemes.
The FSD regime allows the Pensions Regulator to impose an obligation on group companies to provide financial support to underfunded pension schemes.
The Pensions Regulator can impose a Contribution Notice (CN) as a monetary liability on non-compliant target companies.
Several UK registered members of the Lehman and Nortel groups went into insolvent administration.
A Lehman group company entered into service contracts and ran a pension scheme for employees of other group members.
A Nortel group company had a pension scheme that was insufficiently resourced to fund it.
The pension schemes in both cases were final salary schemes in substantial deficit.
The Pensions Regulator initiated FSD machinery to require target companies to provide financial support for the pension schemes.
The Supreme Court ruled that liabilities under the FSD regime issued after an insolvent event rank as provable debts, not as expenses of administration.
The liability under the FSD regime, if issued after an insolvent event, falls within rule 13.12(1)(b) of the Insolvency Rules 1986.
uksc-2018-0164: Barclays Bank is being asked by the Supreme Court to determine if it is vicariously liable for sexual assaults allegedly committed by Dr Gordon Bates between 1968 and 1984.
Dr Gordon Bates was a self-employed medical practitioner with a portfolio practice.
Dr Bates conducted medical assessments and examinations of prospective Barclays employees.
Barclays required job applicants to pass a pre-employment medical examination as part of its recruitment procedures.
Barclays arranged the appointments with Dr Bates and provided him with a pro forma report headed "Barclays Confidential Medical Report."
Dr Bates was paid a fee for each medical report, and Barclays did not pay him a retainer.
If the medical report was satisfactory, the applicants' job offer would be confirmed, subject to satisfactory GCE examination results.
Dr Bates conducted the medical examinations in a consulting room at his home, without chaperone.
The claimants allege that Dr Bates sexually assaulted 126 individuals during their medical examinations.
The Supreme Court unanimously held that Barclays is not vicariously liable for Dr Bates' alleged wrongdoing.
uksc-2014-0138: The appeal challenges the compatibility of s 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994 with article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
s 60 allows a police officer to stop and search a person or vehicle for offensive weapons or dangerous instruments without reasonable suspicion.
The use of s 60 requires authorization from a senior police officer, which must be limited in time and place.
On 9 September 2010, Superintendent Barclay authorized s 60 searches for 17 hours in parts of Haringey to address gang-related violence.
Police Constable Jacqui Reid used s 60 to search Mrs Roberts' bag during an incident involving a fare dispute.
Mrs Roberts denied having identification and kept a tight hold on her bag during the encounter.
The search under s 60 enabled the discovery of Mrs Roberts' name from a bank card.
Mrs Roberts brought judicial review proceedings alleging breaches of her ECHR rights, including article 8.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mrs Roberts' appeal, finding the s 60 power was in accordance with the law.
The Supreme Court held that safeguards in s 60, such as requiring reasons for authorization and searches, ensure lawful exercise of the power.
uksc-2011-0233: The appellant was 17 years old at the time of the incident.
The appellant had sexual intercourse with a 13-year-old girl.
The girl initially informed her mother that the intercourse was not consensual.
The girl later withdrew the allegation and admitted the sex was consensual.
The appellant was arrested and charged with unlawful carnal knowledge of a girl under 14.
The offence under section 4 of the 1885 Act carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.
The appellant pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 3 years in a Young Offenders Centre, suspended for 2 years.
The appellant believed that the defence of reasonable belief in the girl's age was not required.
The Northern Ireland Court of Appeal rejected the appellant's argument that a defence of belief in the girl's age existed.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appellant's appeal.
uksc-2015-0238: N is a profoundly disabled man in his twenties who requires constant care.
N's parents were unable to cooperate with authorities in meeting his care needs.
A care order was made for N when he was eight years old.
The care order ended when N turned eighteen.
The local authority issued proceedings in the Court of Protection seeking orders under the Mental Capacity Act 2005.
The local authority sought orders for N to reside in a care home and for contact with his parents to be supervised.
Responsibility for N's care passed to the National Health Service when he turned 18.
It was not in dispute that N lacked the capacity to make decisions about his residence or contact with his family.
The care home provides a safe and settled environment for N.
The Court of Protection could not order the respondent to fund the parents' proposed care plan.
uksc-2017-0160: The appeal concerns the effect of the GLA Roads and Side Roads (Transfer of Property etc) Order 2000 and the GLA Roads Designation Order 2000.
Responsibility for GLA roads was transferred from London borough councils to TfL under these Orders.
Article 2(1)(a) of the Transfer Order governs the transfer of highway property and liabilities.
TfL and the Councils conducted a statutory arbitration to determine what property and liabilities transferred.
The dispute centers on whether the transfer included only the zone of ordinary use or the entire vertical plane.
